description: From Middle English clift, from Old English ġeclyft, from Proto-Germanic *(ga)kluftiz. Compare Dutch klucht (“coarse comedy”), Swedish klyft (“cave, den”), German Kluft. See cleave.

entries.meaning: An opening, fissure, or V-shaped indentation made by or as if by splitting.
examples: Then came some palsied oak, a cleft in him / Like a distorted mouth that splits its rim / Gaping at death, and dies while it recoils.

entries.meaning: A disease of horses; a crack on the band of the pastern.

verbs.description: cleft (third-person singular simple present clefts, present participle clefting, simple past and past participle clefted)

entries.meaning: (linguistics) To syntactically separate a prominent constituent from the rest of the clause that concerns it, such as threat in "The threat which I saw but which he didn't see, was his downfall."
split, divided, or partially divided into two.
simple past tense and past participle of cleave
